item.title: TRISEP 2016 Summer School in Subatomic Particle Physics
item.creator: acanepa
item.description: TRISEP 2016 Summer School in Subatomic Particle Physics Dear colleagues, We draw your attention to TRISEP 2016, a summer school for graduate students in subatomic particle physics. The school has been held annually since 2013 and is organized in collaboration between the Perimeter Institute, SNOLab and TRIUMF. This year the school will take place at TRIUMF, in Vancouver, Canada, from June 20 – July 1. More details about the school and a link to registration can be found at the... More »
item.comment:
TRISEP 2016 Summer School in Subatomic Particle Physics

Dear colleagues,

We draw your attention to TRISEP 2016, a summer school for graduate students in subatomic particle physics. The school has been held annually since 2013 and is organized in collaboration between the Perimeter Institute, SNOLab and TRIUMF. This year the school will take place at TRIUMF, in Vancouver, Canada, from June 20 – July 1. More details about the school and a link to registration can be found at the website: http://www.trisep.ca/

We have a very exciting program scheduled for graduate students of all levels in both experiment and theory who are familiar with the basics of quantum field theory. The topics to be covered include:

Standard Model and beyond
Neutrino physics
Higgs physics
Dark matter
Techniques for particle colliders
Particle detection methods

These topics will be presented by world experts in the respective fields, including:

Nathaniel Craig (UC Santa Barbara)
Glen Cowan (Royal Holloway)
Gilles Gerbier (Queen’s)
Stefania Gori (U Cincinnati)
Heather Gray (CERN)
Boris Kayser (Fermilab)
Frank Krauss (IPP Durham)
Michael Ramsey-Musolf (U Mass Amherst)
Fabrice Retiere (TRIUMF)
Hirohisa Tanaka (U Toronto)
Brigitte Vachon (McGill)
Manuella Vincter (Carleton)

We thank you in advance for sharing this information with the graduate students in your group or department. A poster for the school is attached. Please also let us know if you would like a printed paper copy of the poster, or if you have any questions about the school.

Sincerely,

The local organizing committee:

Alison Lister
David Morrissey
Dugan O’Neill
Scott Oser
Oliver Stelzer-Chilton

Poster:
2016-03-17_56ead428aaf69_TRISEP-2016.pdf

item.title: Hands-on: Evaluate CompactDAQ and LabVIEW for Your Application on April 20
item.creator: karlix
item.description: In this complimentary three-hour hands-on session with National Instruments, you will be able to understand key steps in system configuration, build example data acquisition applications using a variety of sensor types, including temperature, strain, vibration, and light. You will also familiarize yourself with automating measurement acquisition and signal processing. Space is limited. The session will be held at the Training Center, Rd. A-1, Computer Training Room from 9 a.m.-12 p.m. To register for this event, please visit http://www-esh.fnal.gov/pls/default/schedule.show_course_details?cid=9219
item.comment: In this complimentary three-hour hands-on session with National Instruments, you will be able to understand key steps in system configuration, build example data acquisition applications using a variety of sensor types, including temperature, strain, vibration, and light. You will also familiarize yourself with automating measurement acquisition and signal processing. Space is limited. The session will be held at the Training Center, Rd. A-1, Computer Training Room from 9 a.m.-12 p.m. To register for this event, please visit http://www-esh.fnal.gov/pls/default/schedule.show_course_details?cid=9219

item.title: Developing Monitoring and Control Systems with LabVIEW and CompactRIO hands-on seminar on April 20, 1-4 p.m.
item.creator: karlix
item.description: In this complimentary three-hour session you will see how to use LabVIEW to design custom monitoring and control systems with field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), real-time operating systems, and analog I/O. You will learn how to develop LabVIEW Real-Time and LabVIEW FPGA applications for better code reuse and easier debugging. You will also conduct hands-on exercises with NI CompactRIO, including data flow and parallelism and network communication. Space is limited. The session will be held at the Training Center, Rd. A-1,... More »
item.comment: In this complimentary three-hour session you will see how to use LabVIEW to design custom monitoring and control systems with field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), real-time operating systems, and analog I/O. You will learn how to develop LabVIEW Real-Time and LabVIEW FPGA applications for better code reuse and easier debugging. You will also conduct hands-on exercises with NI CompactRIO, including data flow and parallelism and network communication. Space is limited. The session will be held at the Training Center, Rd. A-1, Computer Training Room from 1pm-4pm. To register for this event, please visit http://www-esh.fnal.gov/pls/default/schedule.show_course_details?cid=8320

item.title: April wellness
item.creator: jkoester
item.description: Get fit and have fun with upcoming wellness classes and events.
item.comment:
APRIL WELLNESS COMPLIMENTARY WELLNESS

Lunch & Learn: Change your legs. Change your life. You don’t have to live with unattractive & painful veins. Learn about treatment for a variety of vein issues. Vein specialists identify causes of vein issues and provide effective nonsurgical solutions. Lunch provided for first 20 to RSVP. Hosted by Vein Clinics of America.

Wednesday, April 13
Wilson Hall, Curia II: 12-1 p.m. RSVP by April 6 to jecker@fnal.gov or x2548

 

FITNESS CLASSES

Fit Camp full body conditioning for all fitness levels using body weight exercises and weighted movements. Improve strength and endurance. Increase mobility and flexibility.
Mondays and Wednesdays: April 4 – May 26
Fitness Center Exercise Room: 4:45 p.m.-5:30 p.m.
Fee: $140 for 16 sessions (Register by March 28)

Mat Pilates
Mondays: April 25 – June 13 (no class May 30)
Fitness Center Exercise Room: 12-12:45 p.m.
Fee: $87 (Register by April 18)

Small Group Training
Semi-private training (group of 3) by a personal trainer.
Mondays and Wednesdays: April 4 – May 26
Fitness Center Exercise Room: 4-4:45 p.m. or 5:30-6:15 p.m.
Fee: $275 for 16 sessions (Register by March 28)

 

ATHLETIC LEAGUES/OPEN GYM

Open Broomball
Broomball is a year-round sport – think field hockey with homemade “brooms” (we have extras) and a large tennis ball. Pick-up games at lunchtime in the Fitness Center gym (membership required) or outdoors. Contact Chris Greer at cgreer@fnal.gov or x4847.

Fermilab Golf League League provides competitive, handicapped, 4-person team matches at Bliss Creek in Sugar Grove on Tuesday and Wednesday nights. Current roster has players of all abilities and genders. Openings for individuals and teams playing on a regular basis and for individuals as needed. Contact Mike at x4091, matulik@fnal.gov

Coed Softball League
Fermi co-ed softball has openings for male and female players. Games are once a week in the Village on Wednesdays or Thursdays, May – September. No experience necessary. Contact Chris Greer at cgreer@fnal.gov or x4847.

item.title: One look for one lab
item.creator: leah
item.description: Our public websites, presentation and document templates, business cards, brochures, exhibits, and even our email signatures have all gotten a makeover.
item.comment:
Katie Yurkewicz

Are you about to create a new presentation, send a memo, write a project note, assemble a meeting agenda or design a poster for a conference? Have you been thinking of updating your email signature or wondering if you’re using the latest lab letterhead?

The Fermilab Graphics Standards website is your one-stop shop for lab-branded document and presentation templates, Fermilab logos, email signatures, and design guidelines including colors and fonts.

As of last week, the suite of templates available on the Graphics Standards site now includes project/experiment notes, visit/meeting agendas, MOUs, scientific posters and fact sheets in addition to updated PowerPoint and Keynote presentations, letterheads and memos. Most templates are available in several versions.

You’re all familiar with the physical infrastructure modernization that has brought so many needed upgrades and changes to the lab site. In parallel with our physical renovation, the Office of Communication has been renovating the look and feel of our communication products — ensuring that the face we present to the world through our communications matches a modern, international and innovative lab at the forefront of science and technology.

Over the last two years the Office of Communication has worked to develop a modern, consistent look and feel for many of our communication products. Our public websites, presentation and document templates, business cards, brochures, exhibits, and even our email signatures have all received a makeover — and will continue to be improved and upgraded in the years to come.

But our work is by no means finished. We need your help to continue to improve our communications to our colleagues, the scientific community and the public. We’re looking for feedback on existing templates and ideas for new ones. Please contact the Creative Services department and let us know what you think, and what you need.

Katie Yurkewicz is the Fermilab assistant director for communications.

item.title: Science agency leaders discuss “Future of U.S. Science”
item.creator: leah
item.description: The President's science advisor and scientists from three federal agencies talk about fundamental science, computing and applied research in the United States at the recent AAAS meeting.
item.comment:
Pushpalatha Bhat

President Obama’s Science Advisor John Holdren and the leaders of three key federal agencies spoke at a symposium at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) in Washington D.C., in February on “Grand Visions for the Future of U.S. Science in a New Global Era.” As a member of the Physics and Societal Impacts of Science & Engineering Sections of the AAAS, I organized and moderated the session.

Holdren, who presented the view from the White House, said that science, technology and innovation (known as ST&I) are central to meeting key challenges of economic growth, health care, clean energy and national security, as well as to “lifting the human spirit through discovery, invention and expanded understanding.” He emphasized that the Obama administration has taken the advice of the ST&I community to an extraordinary degree, subject to constraints of budget. He outlined a number of ST&I priorities and initiatives under President Obama and argued that, with his vision for science, the President has also charted a practical path and walked the walk.

NSF Director France Córdova talked about the research program at all scales of science that the NSF supports — the smallest scales studied through experimental particle physics to the cosmic scales in astronomy and astrophysics. She also talked about some new cross-agency initiatives, about global STEM education and increasing international partnerships. Undersecretary for Science and Energy Lynn Orr emphasized that fundamental scientific research is essential to our energy future, and that the Department of Energy funds scientific research through 10 national labs and three applied energy research labs. He talked about the neutrino science research at Fermilab and other basic science areas as well as exascale computing and its potential in simulations of complex systems and processes. Administrator Bolden, head of NASA, made remarks on NASA’s ambitious program to send American astronauts to Mars in the 2030s and to asteroids before then, how NASA’s satellites are studying our own planet, and on studies on the International Space Station. He said that the future of NASA is strong. It is helping us to uncover the secrets of the universe and to create the future, and as President Obama said, “We are pushing farther into the solar system, not just to visit, but to stay.”

A panel discussion on globalization, international partnerships and public outreach, as well as a Q&A with the audience, followed.

View slides of talks from Drs. Holdren, Córdova and Orr.

Pushpa Bhat is a Fermilab physicist and a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Pushpa Bhat led a panel discussion on the future of science in the United States during a symposium at the recent AAAS meeting.

item.title: Safety reminder: construction and Fermilab roads
item.creator: jemila
item.description: Fermilab is in the midst of extensive growth and development to expand physics programs, and to upgrade aging infrastructure to ensure many more decades of continued research. Five construction projects are currently under way that involve excavating and transporting soil and gravel.  Construction crews monitor and clean the roads as necessary, but mud and loose gravel can accumulate, posing a slip and fall hazard.  Motorists, bicyclists and pedestrians are reminded to use extra caution when traveling on roads that are... More »
item.comment:
Fermilab is in the midst of extensive growth and development to expand physics programs, and to upgrade aging infrastructure to ensure many more decades of continued research. Five construction projects are currently under way that involve excavating and transporting soil and gravel.  Construction crews monitor and clean the roads as necessary, but mud and loose gravel can accumulate, posing a slip and fall hazard.  Motorists, bicyclists and pedestrians are reminded to use extra caution when traveling on roads that are used for construction activities.

By working together, we can keep everyone safe while Fermilab reinforces its reputation as America’s premier particle physics laboratory.

item.title: Barn Dance March 20
item.creator: garren
item.description: The Fermilab Folk Club presents a Barn Dance on Sunday, March 20 at 2 p.m. in the Kuhn Village Barn with music by Too Old to be Controlled and calling by Martha Tyner. Everyone is welcome. You don’t need to know anything, just come and have fun! Admission is $6, children under 12 are free, 12 to 18 year olds and people over 65 are $3. More info and directions at http://www.fnal.gov/orgs/folkclub/

item.title: New Fermilab document templates available
item.creator: leah
item.description: An updated and greatly expanded set of Fermilab-branded document templates is now available on the Fermilab Graphics Standards website. Updated templates include: Revised PowerPoint and Keynote presentations, including versions that accommodate partner logos Color and black-and-white letterhead and memo documents Brand-new templates include: Document/project notes in portrait and landscape orientation with multiple cover options Visit/meeting agendas MOU documents Fact sheets and three different sizes of scientific posters The Graphics Standards website is also your one-stop shop for other Fermilab design... More »
item.comment:
An updated and greatly expanded set of Fermilab-branded document templates is now available on the Fermilab Graphics Standards website. Updated templates include:

  • Revised PowerPoint and Keynote presentations, including versions that accommodate partner logos
  • Color and black-and-white letterhead and memo documents

Brand-new templates include:

  • Document/project notes in portrait and landscape orientation with multiple cover options
  • Visit/meeting agendas
  • MOU documents
  • Fact sheets and three different sizes of scientific posters

The Graphics Standards website is also your one-stop shop for other Fermilab design elements, such as:

  • Logos: Downloadable Fermilab logos and guidelines for use, information about organizational logos, and guidelines for presenting the Fermilab, DOE and FRA logos together
  • Email signatures
  • The Fermilab color palette
  • Recommended fonts for internal and external communications

If you have any questions or comments or need assistance with the document templates or any other graphic standards elements, please contact the Creative Services Department at x3349 or creativeservices@fnal.gov .
